abstract.p: Rebecca Blady letter holds that Thomas Egan makes fair point in calling late teenage years most hazardous time in child's life; maintains that our educational institutions should teach consequences of common hazardous teenage activities instead of attacking teenagers' innate instincts, and leaving them to find answers themselves (June 9 Op-Ed)

block.p: In ''The Boy in the Coffin'' (column, June 9), Timothy Egan makes a fair point in calling a child's late teenage years ''the most hazardous time of their lives.''
In ''The Boy in the Coffin'' (column, June 9), Timothy Egan makes a fair point in calling a child's late teenage years ''the most hazardous time of their lives.''
As a teenager, I can personally attest to this description. My peers engage in unhealthy experimentation with their bodies daily. Often, parents are completely oblivious.

But I do not agree with the solutions Mr. Egan suggests. Restrictions will not cure a teenager of his or her free spirit; a natural side effect of these late teenage years is the desire to explore and create.
Instead of trying to halt this desire for independence, relevant authorities should channel teenagers' emotions to more appropriate places. Education is the only acceptable answer.

Perhaps our educational institutions should teach the consequences of common hazardous teenage activities instead of attacking teenagers' innate instincts, and leaving them to find the answers themselves.
Rebecca Blady North Woodmere, N.Y., June 9, 2007
